text:
RIITTA KATILA: You've
got a great idea,

so how do you sell this idea to
your boss and your boss's boss?

How do you get buy-in from
teammates and your stakeholders

and the time and the resources
you need to make it happen?

I'm Riitta Katila,
and I've spent decades

working with
successful innovators

and consulting with the top
Silicon Valley companies
on how to foster innovation.

In this course, I'll share some
of the most important lessons

I've learned about how to build
key workplace relationships,

cultivate influence
across any organization,
and make your voice heard.

We'll provide you
with a set of tools

so you can learn how
to frame your pitch,

align your idea with your
organization's goals,

and garner support
from your colleagues.
What is a good pitch?

MICHAEL TODASCO: A good pitch
is knowing your audience.
It's wowing your audience.

RIITTA KATILA: You'll
get practical advice

from business leaders
about how they

pitched their innovative
ideas successfully and learned
from their failures.

EMILY MA: We actually had
to fail at every level

to realize, oh,
we have to go down

to the very foundational
layer and figure out

how to rework this before
everything else can percolate.

GRACE ISFORD: You
want to focus not only

on simplifying the idea, but
focusing on the key points that
matter to those stakeholders.

NICK OKAFOR: We
wanted to make sure

that before we pitch to the CEO,
that we had our own champions.

Maybe you get some interviews,
you get some feedback.

RIITTA KATILA: Together, we'll
develop an actionable strategy

to capture the attention
and imagination

of senior management and
develop your innovation

skills for long-term
professional success.

Join us from wherever you
are at Stanford Online.
